facts.text: Civil Appeal No 1655 of 1968 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 1655 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 811 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 811 of 1965.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Grover, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.

facts.text: Respondent entered into a deed of lease on October 26, 1951 with the appellant in respect of premises Nos. 8 9, Mahatma Gandhi Road, South Parade, Civil Station, Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent entered into a deed of lease on October 26, 1951 with the appellant in respect of premises Nos. 8 9, Mahatma Gandhi Road,  South Parade , Civil Station, Bangalore.

facts.text: Lease for a period of 10 years in the first instance with effect from November 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It was stipulated that the lease would be for a period of 10 years in the first instance with effect from November 1, 1961 with ,an option

facts.text: Lessee has option to renew the lease after every 10 years as long as desired.

anchor.surface_text: with ,an option to the lessee to renew the same as long as desired as provided. Clauses 9 and 10 which are material may be reproduced--

facts.text: Clause 9: Lessee shall have the right to renew the lease at the end of ten years on same rental of Rs. 450/- per month for similar periods thereafter on same terms.

anchor.surface_text: The lessee shall have the right to renew the lease of the scheduled premises at the end of the present period of ten years herein secured on the same rental of Rs. 450/- per month, for a similar period and for further similar periods thereafter on the same terms and companyditions as are set forth herein

facts.text: Clause 10: Lessor shall not raise any objection to lessee exercising option to renew for further periods of ten years as long as they desire, provided lessee does not transfer the lease.

anchor.surface_text: and the Lessee shall be permitted and shall have the right to remain in occupation of the premises on the same terms and companyditions for any further periods of ten years as long as they desire to do so. The Lessor shall number raise any objection whatsoever to the Lessee exercising his option to renew the lease for any further periods of ten years on the same terms and companyditions as long as they desire to be in occupation, provided that the Lessee shah number have the right to transfer the lease or alienate any right thereunder.

facts.text: Before expiry of the period of ten years from commencement of lease, lessee wrote to lessor informing intention to exercise option to renew for ten years from November 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the expiry of the period of ten years from the date of the companymencement of the lease the lessee wrote to the lessor informing him of the intention to exercise the option given to the lessee under the deed of lease to get the same renewed on the same terms and companyditions as before for a period of ten years from November 1, 1961.

facts.text: Lessor did not comply with the lessee's request to renew.

anchor.surface_text: The lessor did number companyply with the request.

facts.text: Lessee served notice and filed suit for specific performance of covenant for renewal.

anchor.surface_text: After serving a numberice the lessee filed a suit for specific performance of the companyenant in the lease for renewal.

facts.text: Suit prayed for lessor to execute registered deed of lease or court to do so.

anchor.surface_text: It was prayed that the lessor be directed to execute a registered deed to lease in favour of the lessee and if he failed to do so the companyrt should execute a deed in his favour.

facts.text: Lessor pleaded that condition relating to renewal was hit by rule against perpetuity.

anchor.surface_text: The lessor pleaded, inter alia, that the companydition relating to renewal was hit the rule against perpetuity.

facts.text: Trial court decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt decreed the suit.

facts.text: First appellate court and High Court affirmed the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellate companyrt and the High Court affirmed the decree.

facts.text: Lease was for a period of ten years only in the first instance, not a lease in perpetuity.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed on behalf of the appellant that a lease in perpetuity companyld have been created but the lease in the present case was number of that kind and was for a period of ten years only in the first instance.

facts.text: Renewal clauses are covenants that run with the land.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the mischief is created by the clauses relating to renewal which are companyenants that run with the land.

facts.text: K. Sen, Shyamala Pappu and Vineet Kumar appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: K. Sen, Shyamala Pappu and Vineet Kumar, for the appellant.

facts.text: V. Gupte, Janendra Lal, B.R. Agarwala and Kumar M. Mehta appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Janendra Lal, B.R. Agarwala and Kumar M. Mehta, for the respondent.

facts.text: Monthly rental stipulated as Rs. 450/- per month.

concepts.interpretation: No transfer of property can operate to create an interest which is to take effect after the lifetime of one or more persons living at the date of such transfer and the minority of some person who shall be in existence at the expiration of that period.

arguments.court_reasoning: Renewal option is not a transfer creating remote interest under s.14; it is a personal covenant not amounting to interest in property.

arguments.claim: the lease in the present case was for a period of ten years only in the first instance and not a lease in perpetuity

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed on behalf of the appellant that a lease in perpetuity could have been created but the lease in the present case was not of that kind and was for a period of ten years only in the first instance.

arguments.court_reasoning: Clauses do not create transferable interest vesting remotely; s.14 applies only to transfers of property.

arguments.claim: Section 14 is applicable only where there is transfer of property

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. Section 14 is applicable only where there is transfer of property.

arguments.claim: the transfer was for a period of ten years only by means of the indenture Exh. P-I. The stipulation relating to the renewal could not be regarded as transferring property or any rights therein

anchor.surface_text: Even if creation of a lease-hold interest is a transfer of a right in property and would fall within the expression transfer of property the transfer was for a period of ten years only by means of the indenture Exh. P-I. The stipulation relating to the renewal could not be regarded as transferring property or any rights therein.

arguments.claim: in Ganesh Sonar v. Purnendu Narayan Singha the option given was merely a personal covenant and not one creating an interest in land so rule against perpetuity not applicable

anchor.surface_text: In Ganesh Sonar v. Purnendu Narayan Singha Ors. in the case of lease of land an option had been given to the lessor determine the lease and take possession of the lease- hold land under specified conditions. ... According to the Patna decision the option given by the lessee to the lessor to resume the lease hold land was merely a personal covenant and was not a covenant which created an interest in land and so. the rule against perpetuity contained in s. 14 of the Act was not applicable.

arguments.claim: the same principle would govern the present case as the clauses containing the option to get the lease renewed do not create an interest in property within s.14

anchor.surface_text: The same principle would govern the present case. The clauses containing the option to get the lease renewed on the expiry of each term of ten years can by no means be regarded as creating an interest in property

arguments.claim: even under English law a covenant for perpetual renewal is valid and not objectionable on ground of perpetuity

anchor.surface_text: Even under the English law the court would give effect to a covenant for perpetual renewal so long as the intention is clear and it will not be open to objection on the ground of perpetuity see Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd Edn. Vol. 23, p 627. In Muller v. Traf Jword it was held that the covenant in a lease for renewal was not strictly a covenant for renewal.

arguments.claim: the equitable rule that the burden of a covenant runs with the land in s.40 applies and such covenants are not interests in land or easements

anchor.surface_text: The equitable rule that the burden of a covenant runs with the land is to be found in s. 40 of the Act. ... s. 40 expressly says that the right of the covenantee is not an interest in the land bound by the covenant nor an easement.

holdings.text: Section 14 is applicable only where there is transfer of property

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. Section 14 is applicable only where there is transfer of property. Even if creation of a lease-hold interest is a transfer of a right in property and would fall within the expression transfer of property the transfer was for a period of ten years only by means of the indenture Exh. P-I.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14 by its terms governs transfers of property; renewal option separate from initial lease transfer

holdings.text: The transfer was for a period of ten years only by means of the indenture Exh. P-I. The stipulation relating to the renewal could not be regarded as transferring property or any rights therein

anchor.surface_text: Even if creation of a lease-hold interest is a transfer of a right in property and would fall within the expression transfer of property the transfer was for a period of ten years only by means of the indenture Exh. P-I. The stipulation relating to the renewal could not be regarded as transferring property or any rights therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Initial lease transfers interest for fixed 10 years; renewal clause is separate stipulation not effecting further transfer at inception

holdings.text: The clauses containing the option to get the lease renewed on the expiry of each term of ten years can by no means be regarded as creating an interest in property of the nature that would fall within the ambit of s. 14

anchor.surface_text: The same principle would govern the present case. The clauses containing the option to get the lease renewed on the expiry of each term of ten years can by no means be regarded as creating an interest in property of the nature that would fall within the ambit of s. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Renewal options are personal covenants analogous to option in Ganesh Sonar case, not creating remote vesting interests

holdings.text: The rule against perpetuity contained in s. 14 of the Act was not applicable

anchor.surface_text: the rule against perpetuity contained in s. 14 of the Act was not applicable. The same principle would govern the present case. The clauses containing the option to get the lease renewed on the expiry of each term of ten years can by no means be regarded as creating an interest in property

holdings.reasoning_summary: Renewal clauses do not create interest vesting after perpetuity period under s.14 as they are not transfers of property

holdings.text: The right of the covenantee is not an interest in the land bound by the covenant nor an easement

anchor.surface_text: s. 40 expressly says that the right of the covenantee is not an interest in the land bound by the covenant nor an easement. It is not an interest because the Act does not recognise equitable estates and it cannot be said as Sir George Jessel said in London South Western Rly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.40 TPA governs running of covenant burdens; expressly excludes them from being interests or easements attracting s.14

holdings.text: Even under the English law the court would give effect to a covenant for perpetual renewal so long as the intention is clear and it will not be open to objection on the ground of perpetuity

anchor.surface_text: Even under the English law the court would give effect to a covenant for perpetual renewal so long as the intention is clear and it will not be open to objection on the ground of perpetuity see Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd Edn. Vol. 23, p 627.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supportive reference to English authorities like Halsbury and cases confirming validity of perpetual renewal covenants
